description.text:
There are Adjustable Z Stops on here for the CR-10, all but one do not have adjusters, you just loosen the screws while holding the plate and trust that you can move it .5 mm then hold it while you tighten the screws back up. Well everyone must be more coordinated than me, because I couldn't do it.
So here is the "Better Than Nothing" Adjustable Z Stop for the CR-10.

I use a 3mm x 20mm screw and 2 lock nuts. one goes in the little box and acts to hold the screw in place and the other goes on the bottom of the screw so it has a larger surface area to press against the base plate. You will need to replace the M5 x 10mm screw that holds the T Frame support with a M5 x 12 screw to hold the base plate and the T Frame support
.
I start with the screw adjusted to about the middle, so I can go up or down as needed. I tighten the M5 screws to hold it in place.Then I do the Auto home and level the bed for that height. Then I can loosen the M5 screws a little and do fine adjustments to the Z stop by turning the 3mm screw and tightening the M5 screws back up if my extrusion flow is not right, without re leveling the bed every time.
I hope this works for you as well as it has for me.

description.text:
I designed this mount to move the Z-motor to bottom hoping that this will made the whole Z-axis movement smoother, I printed a low quality test and check the fittings and all fits perfectly with the stock Anet A2.

If you are planning to use this part, please make sure to print it strong enough as it will carry the whole X axis weight. also you must know that you need to change the direction for the Z motor, this can be done by switching the wires in the plug or by firmware.
Designed using Fusion 360.

This is a two part make of a micro fusion cell from Fallout 4. You can print the fusion cell in yellow for the base and black for the top. 160mm version. The mold can be scaled to any size.

Instructions:
1.The inside surface must be smoothed. Something like XTC-3D is recommended to save time.

This has been my daily driver for five years.

title: Fidget Spinner (TheFabLab)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Si tratta di un semplice Fidget Spinner, progettato con Open SCAD, un programma di progettazione parametrico, open source e piuttosto diffuso in ambito educativo.

È un primo esempio, semplice, della cosiddetta progettazione parametrica. Lavorando con questo approccio è possibile immaginare una personalizzazione estremamente spinta dei prodotti di consumo. Immagina per esempio di personalizzare la forma e le dimensioni di un arredo o di capo di abbigliamento. La piattaforma su cui ci troviamo è progettata con finalità didattiche ed educative e offre opportunità ancora limitate, ma delle quali si scorge già il potenziale.

Sono diverse le corporation che stanno studiando il modo migliore di integrare le opportunità offerte da questo approccio nel loro piano di sviluppo aziendale.

title: Centrifugal Fan 12 v
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi this is a simple 12VDC centrifugal fan with backward curved impellers (make sure you get the polarity correct! This will maximize the airflow and efficiency. To further maximize efficiency and reduce noise, get a motor with 6 stators, I use a motor with 4 stators and it works fine, if a little noisy. This puts about the same amount of air for me as a hairdryer on low setting. I plan to add a bell inlet to improve efficiency further. Stay tuned for updates!

I got the motor from Princess Auto and had to dremel out the hub to be able to persuade the impeller onto the shaft.

The bottom plate is extra thick, while the shell is thinner to save on printing. Three screws hold the fan together, If your motor mount plate is warped, you will have an issue with the blades hitting the casing.

Enjoy!

2018-02-05 UPDATE!

Added a transition piece to fit 4" circular ducting, and also a bell inlet that has been optimized to minimize intake losses giving a marginal improvement to CFM.

The fan has been tested now using a vane anemometer and produces at least 30 CFM. (there may be some leaks as i checked outlet flow running through a solar air heater I built!).

title: SP101 (.327) Speed Loader
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 7/6/17 Couple of improvements for the speed loader. First, I added grooves to the bottom of the body to assist the center shaft insertion without jeopardizing the strength of the detent's flexibility. Now you can very easily guide the detents into the holes in the body without weakening the "clicking action". The shaft itself has also been beefed up around the flexing area, and the bottom feet have a tighter gap. This has also helped cure the issue of the shaft being able to turn a full 360 degrees within the body when to much force was applied. The detents should now only be able to travel the originally intended 30 degrees. I had to do a little clean up on my first layers of the body and the gap in between the center shaft's feet, but I am extremely impressed at the outcome. Much better than the original shafts locking and clicking ability.This new shaft will have to be used with the new body. I think if you try to put it into the old body, it just won't fit, but nothing says you can't cut your own guide grooves into the bottom of the old body to accept the new shaft. If you experience the detents not clicking from open to close, simply cut some of the gap away in between the feet of the center shaft. I'm trying to keep tolerances tight so the speed loader will last a long time, but I know not all of us have the same printers, or use the same settings. So always make sure you trim, and test before you glue! Hopefully here soon, we won't have to glue any more. That way parts will be easily replaceable if needed. Enjoy, and remember that comments and suggestions are always welcome.

Speed loader for the Ruger SP101 .327 caliber revolvers. This is designed to be 100% printed, no springs or ball bearings needed for assembly. Also no supports needed either, the parts are simply glued together once your happy with the release of the rounds. (some trimming/ sanding may be required for proper fit. I also used a 3/8 drill bit "by hand" to clean up the holes.) I used PLA for this print with good success. When inserting the shaft with the detents on the sides, it is best to line up the detents with the corresponding holes inside the body. Constant removal of the shaft, or improper assembly can cause the PLA to lose some strength, weakening the "clicking action". Another material that's made to flex without breaking may be a better choice for the center shaft. I made this loader with a counter clockwise release, and plan on making a few tweaks down the road. Like having all the pieces snap together instead of having to use glue, and also making a better detent system. But for right now, I'm enjoying mine, they seem to work fairly well. Even better once you start using them more and the plastic breaks in.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.100

Infill:

25%

print_settings.Notes:: Microswiss mod
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Spool support with built in perforated dessicant holder sized for Hatchbox spools

I mount my spools on the shelf above my printer and thread the filament thru a hole drilled in the container lid down into my printer box using a 3 inch length of 2mm ID PTFE tubing from Banggood held in place by a combination of hot melt glue and some random 4mm ID tubing and heat shrink tubing [it works, OK?!]

The whole contraption allows me to print PETG in my garage without any obvious humidity-related issues [Eastern Virginia gets pretty damp]

Compact size to fit in Rubbermaid 21 cup box https://www.amazon.com/Rubbermaid-21-Cup-Dry-Food-Container/dp/B003EYUZJU/ref=sr_1_1?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1499185439&sr=1-1&keywords=rubbermaid+21+cup

Bearings are the rather wimpy 624VV https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-624VV-4mm-V-Groove-Sealed-Ball-Bearings-Wire-Guide-Pulley-Wheels-Roller-p-1034375.html?rmmds=search mounted on #8 bolts but you can use whatever grooved bearings fit in the bearing supports

The axle holes are slightly undersized for #8 bolts - you can either ream them out slightly or use M4 bolts.
I was able to tap a thread in them with the #8 bolts but even PETG will split if you apply too much force

The gap between bearing supports is 10mm but my bearings are 6mm wide - hence the washers on either side.

As you can see in the picture there's obviously a fair bit of underextrusion present in my print but the walls are more than sturdy enough to compensate

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.36mm

Notes:

Microswiss mod

(WARNING) this must be mounted on the gun up side down on the bottom of the gun otherwise it will be off aim by a lot.  
This laser light for Nerf guns is pointing 1 degree down so the aim is more exact.  This holder fits those $2.00 - $5.00 laser pointers you can buy at Petsmart and staples.

print_settings.Notes:: Extruder:215°C first layer, 205°C other layers

title: Roller Spool Holder for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a replacement spool holder for the original Prusa i3 Mk2/Mk2S 3D printer using common, easy-to-obtain 608 bearings for less friction. In the original Prusa spool holder, the spool rests on little stubs. Unfortunately the spool tends to rub on the stubs and the additional friction causes the filament to pull on the print carriage during printing. This holder also retains the spool more securely while still allowing easy spool changes.

The roller w/bearings is mounted on a 1/4-inch aluminum rod using optional bushings.

As a bonus, I've included the design for an expandable roller. I found that the fixed roller works better for my needs most of the time, but the expandable roller is useful for an extra-wide filament spools since the halves of the roller can be fully disengaged to support any width.

Additional Materials Needed:

  • (2) 608 bearings (or 4 for the expandable roller)
  • 7+ inches of 1/4-inch aluminum rod

Tools Needed:

  • Hobby Knife
  • Metal File

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 um

Infill:

25%

Notes:
  • The spool holder arms should be printed in ABS for durability and to allow for some flex without snapping.
  • PLA is recommended for the bearing bushings because PLA allows for more reproducible printed dimensions which are important for proper fit and friction on the metal support rod. The bushings' thin walls are also very difficult to print in ABS.
  • The roller may be printing in either ABS or PLA.

If your Prusa i3 uses the orange color scheme, ABS in Safety Orange is available from Prusa's online store to match the original parts.

For ABS, the following settings are recommended for printing spare parts for the Original Prusa i3 Mk2:

Extruder:255°C first layer, 235°C other layers
Bed:100°C
Vert Perimeters:3
Bottom Layers:3
Top layers:4
Fan:Off
Brim:3 mm



For PLA:

Extruder:215°C first layer, 205°C other layers
Bed:55°C
Vert Perimeters:3
Bottom Layers:3
Top layers:4
Fan:On
Brim:3 mm

1. Remove single layer bridges

The roller has inner stop rings to hold the bearings in position while allowing the metal support rod to pass through. To help print these rings, their bottom layers are closed off with a single layer bridge (see picture.) Use a hobby knife and cut out the single layers closing the rings before inserting the bearings.

2. Insert bearings into the roller

The roller is designed to hold the bearings snugly to slightly loose. A small lip helps holds the bearings in place, but may prevent insertion of the bearings if they are a little too large (especially the one printed on the bed which may be slightly enlarged due to extra first layer squashing.) If necessary, trim the lip with a hobby knife so that the bearing can be inserted without excessive force. Insert two bearings into the fixed-length roller and two bearings into each half of the expandable roller.

3. Insert bushings into bearings

Carefully ream the hole at the base of the bushings so that the bushing will slide onto the support rod. The bushings should have enough friction on the rod to hold the roller in place and prevent it from falling off the rod. Insert one bushing per bearing.

4. Insert metal rod through bearing bushings

Use the metal file to carefully de-burr and lightly bevel the ends of the metal support rod so that it can be inserted through the bushings without damaging them. Insert the rod through the roller bushings.

5. Attach rod caps

Place a rod cap on a sturdy surface and push the metal rod into the hole. If the hole is too small, use a hobby knife to tip the "fingers" back. If the hole is a too large, use a scrap of printed filament (such as the from the brim) to wedge the rod end tightly onto the rod.

6. Add a filament guide

Because this roller spool holder will allow the spool to rotate much more freely, the filament may become loose, fall outside the spool, and become tangled during normal printing as the print carriage tugs slightly on the filament. This much more likely with a full spool. To help prevent this, add a filament guide so that the filament will feed off near the center of the spool. Many different designs are available elsewhere on Thingiverse.

Spool holder arms

The spool holder arms were made by importing the STL files for the original Prusa i3 spool holder into 123D Design and modifying it to hold a rod. The original Prusa i3 spool holder STL file can found here: https://github.com/prusa3d/Original-Prusa-i3/blob/MK2/Printed-Parts/stl/spool%20holdahMK3.stl.

All other parts

All other parts of the spool holder were created by me from scratch in 123D Design.

description.text: I had an adjustable mount, but I found that it loosened up more often than I preferred, so I designed a simple, sturdier version specifically for 8020's 1010 (or 1") profile.

Printer:

Marvin Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Used Hatchbox PLA Filament.

I made this using the 12864 LCD's mounting holes, which are commonly used for many cases, including Scarou's LCD case (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:684778) which is pictured with this.

This was designed in SolidWorks 2016, and the source file is also included here for anyone wishing to tinker further. There is a radius that blends well wiht Scarou's case, so I mirrored the bracket to make an opposite-handed bracket to make it look good.

You can use either 4-40 x 3/4" or M3 x 20mm with this LCD case, as these screws bolt the case and brackets together. Use standard 8020/1010 hardware (1/4-20 flanged button head screws) to mount it to the profile.

title: RBL rebar mount adapter (part 1 of 2) - 1 hole

description.text:
"Really Big Light" rebar base mount / upright position [part 1 of 2]

Please keep in mind this is a working prototype, and I am open to suggestions and ideas.

I decided to print the mount in 2 parts. The reason I did it this way was to be able to print it without ANY support. I tried printed it as one complete part with support, but it took a bit of time to clean it up. Printing it in 2 parts comes out much cleaner, and then I just glued the 2 parts together. The top part is made so you can slide it into a 1/2" piece of PVC for mounting pixel modules to it or other mounted lights (i.e. bullet pixels).

It is designed to mount on top of a 3/8" piece of rebar. It also have a rebar mount screw housing at the bottom of it. This is designed to be used with a #10-32 x 3/4" screw. This with keep the "Really Big Light" from turning on the piece of rebar.

title: CR10 Mosaic Palette Scroll Wheel Mount

description.text:
This is a simple Mosaic Palette scroll wheel mount for the Creality CR-10. It mounts to the X axis stepper, capturing the vertical guide wheel center bolt.

You'll need to cut down one of your output tubes to make use of this mount. I chose to sacrifice the smaller one. I cut the tube so that when the scroll wheel is mounted, the end of the output tube is flush with the input to the extruder.

I load filament with the scroll wheel unmounted, feeding filament manually through the extruder until it just gets to the print head. I then snap the scroll wheel into the mount and feed the remaining millimeters via the control unit move axis. I'd be interested in hearing different/better methods!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

100%

comments.text: How well does the palette work with the bowden setup? I have a CR-10 as well.
comments.author: slimshizn

comments.text:
With the short tube (i.e. this mount) it works well. With the long tube, the distance between the palette and print head is too far, making it difficult for the palette to make corrections during the print. I've lost sync several times using the long tube resulting in an over/undershot color change location.
Be prepared to waste filament though, and I don't only mean the purge tower. You wind up with the Bowden tube full of filament in the end which winds up going in your discard bin.
I also have the Prusa Multimaterial upgrade for my Mk2. Currently it is a toss up which I like better. The Prusa currently locks you in to Slic3r (or KISS), but is much easier to setup print-to-print and handles multiple material types. The Palette (not Plus), really only works well for PLA and is much more involved to get a print going. It does, however, let you use different slicers (i.e. Simplify3D) and allows you to take advantage of the CR10's large build area.
Both devices are somewhat finicky though. The Prusa MM can jam with certain filaments/temperatures/phases-of-the-moon and you can wind up with a print-ruining weak splice with the Palette. Pick your poison.
The Palette Plus (just released) addresses both materials and splice strength issues, but also costs more.

description.text:
"Really Big Light" rebar base mount / upright position [part 1 of 2]

Please keep in mind this is a working prototype, and I am open to suggestions and ideas.

I decided to print the mount in 2 parts. The reason I did it this way was to be able to print it without ANY support. I tried printed it as one complete part with support, but it took a bit of time to clean it up. Printing it in 2 parts comes out much cleaner, and then I just glued the 2 parts together. The top part is made so you can slide it into a 1/2" piece of PVC for mounting pixel modules to it or other mounted lights (i.e. bullet pixels).

It is designed to mount on top of a 3/8" piece of rebar. It also have a rebar mount screw housing at the bottom of it. This is designed to be used with a #10-32 x 3/4" screw. This with keep the "Really Big Light" from turning on the piece of rebar.

description.text:
This is part of a set of customizable Lego compatible robotics components. This post is for parametric Lego compatible TREADS.
(Necessary wheels are a separate Thingi here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2417830) (Thingy's are separate because each is its own customizer.)

Files Included:
*An openscad file for generating any length of tread with any tread pattern you want.

When customizing wheels and treads, to make a perfect fit they must have the same number of teeth. If you want to make a tank tread, use the attached excel calculator to determine the appropriate number of tread teeth. (That or trial and error!)

The wheels should be printed in a hard material like ABS. The treads must be at least semi flexible. The TPU linked below works but is a bit slick for mini-sumo and is tight for stretching. The TPE filament makes ideal high flex high stretch treads.

ABS filament: http://amzn.to/2tzUZoR
TPU filament: http://amzn.to/2uzk3Ja
Very Flexible high friction TPE filament: http://amzn.to/2tkdpY1

Compatible motors:
Gear Motor: http://amzn.to/2tE91Wf
SG90-9g Servo: http://amzn.to/2tEdh8p
FS90R-continuous Servo: http://amzn.to/2tL3XQG

Be sure to check out the rest of my collection of the best customizable Lego parts on Thingiverse: https://www.thingiverse.com/MechEngineerMike/collections/customizable-legos

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 Max

Infill:

Any

Notes:

3D Printing flexible filament is surprisingly easy as long as you have a direct drive extruder. I've even had luck printing on an old printer than didn't have a heated bed.
The semi-flex TPU is the easiest to start with and cheaper. But the highly flexible TPE is an ideal tread material. Print slow....20mm/sec.

description.text:
After making this sofa for my wife as a business card holder, I realized it would make a real nice addition to a dollhouse... so I removed the slot for the business card, and then decided to make it available in various formats... and made an entire ensemble.

Available

As this was designed for a business card holder, the dimensions aren't perfect for a dollhouse... so use your printing / slicing software to print it at the following percentages depending on your need (common dollhouse scales below):

  • 1:12 scale = print at 141%
  • 1:16 scale = print at 106%
  • 1:24 scale = print at 71%
  • 1:48 scale = print at 35%

Original design (Business Card Holder)

As this was designed for a business card holder, the dimensions aren't perfect for a dollhouse... so use your printing / slicing software to print it at the following percentages depending on your need (common dollhouse scales below):

  • 1:12 scale = print at 141%
  • 1:16 scale = print at 106%

author: JordanThomasWright

description.text:
Update 7/6/17: Added sketch used to display the clock.

This is a clock I built for one of my sons who was having trouble knowing whether it was day time or night time

At 7pm the lights all turn purple. Every 30 minutes, one of them goes out until 7am at which point they all turn yellow. The process repeats with a yellow light going out every 30 minutes until 7pm.

This design allowed him to know whether it was day or night and to get a visual sense for how much time was left before either.

Parts:

  • Neopixel ring for Particle Photon / Core
  • A Particle Photon or Core
  • A print of the neopixel_ring.stl to house the neopixel ring itself. I used some double sided foam tape to ensure it doesn't fall out.
  • A print of the front of the case (the ring print should press fit into it)
  • A print of the back of the case (the front of the case should press fit into the back)

Code:

The daynight.ino sketch is what I have running on my photon. It is in the files section. I used the web ide to upload it. It requires the neopixel library which should be importable via the web IDE.

You will want to adjust the timezone in the setup. The sketch does not currently account for daylight savings time so the timezone needs to be updated every six months.

Case:

The case was designed in openscad and is press fit together.

We powered it via the micro USB port for the first year or so until someone pulled on it too hard and damaged the connector. I managed to get the broken connector off and solder wire to a 2.1mm jack to power it as you see in the pictures. I bored out a hole in the side and used hot glue to hold in the jack connector.

My take on X-carriage.
This one is for the combo Budas V2, Wade extruder and LMU10 bearings.
It's actually split into 2 sections. The point is, although the extruder is fixed (=no quick exchange there), you can insert in-between the left and right part one additional extruder..or 2...or 3...
I did not finalize, nor try, the design of this "middle" section. But the design attached here is working really well for almost a year now, without troubles at all.

title: 1/10 scale MB Jeep Wheels For Ossum Jeep

description.text:
These are wheels to go with the 1/10 scale tires I made for my Ossum Jeep. Assemble the inside wheel to the outside wheel with 4 M3 X 8mm long screws. If you want you can use all 8 holes but it doesn't seem like it is needed. The way I see it use only 4 screws and if you strip one hole out you have the other 4 to use. When using my tires, put the wheel half's in the tire and snug up the 4 screws a little at a time until the wheel halves just touch each other. Do not over tighten and work the screws around a little at a time and they should go in nicely.

See the Ossum Jeep at:

description.text:
I like to print hot and cool aggressively, and so after running this duct on my Maker Select for quite awhile, I wanted some better cooling for my D-Bot. I had picked up some 50mm blower fans and saw that no one had made something similar for the D-Bot, so I decided to make my own.

I haven't extensively tested this design, but initial results when doing a overhang test print seems good. There are some weak spots (the interconnecting parts), but it shouldn't be a problem unless the duct collides with something. The stock e3d v6 30mm fan fits with this shroud on.

DualFanMountV2.STL spaces the duct up by 2mm if you want more clearance between the shroud and bed.

The duct part should be printed in ABS due to the close proximity to the hot end block.

Printer:

Maker Select V1 and D-Bot

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Notes:

Print with support only at the fan opening. The other parts don't need it and will be difficult to remove.

Assembly requirements:

  • M3 Screws
  • M3 Nuts
  • Two 50mm blower fans
  1. Assemble everything except the mount.
  2. Attach the mount to the carriage on the side with the fan on top (since the fan will prevent you from tightening this bolt.)
  3. Attach the Bracket to the mount (since the 2nd mount screw will likely be in the way of the screw for attaching the bracket).
  4. Attach the 2nd mount screw.

comments.text:
Great remix/addition. In the video you mention the possibility of punching out a hole for a USB connection. Would you be able to publish an STL off the base with a USB hole? (Otherwise it looks like you'd have to unscrew the base or take off the top every time you need to charge the battery) I'd like to print one for my desk but will want to run it off USB most of the time. I know that is an easy change to make myself but I'm being lazy and figured you might still have the model hand in your environment rather than me importing the STL and hacking in the hole via SketchUp which is my default modeling tool.
Either way looks like a fun print.
comments.author: TinWhiskerz

comments.text: Thank you! Yes, that's a great idea. I think that will make reprogramming a lot easier as well. Check out the thing files, it should be there now. Let me know if the tolerances workout. Cheers!

Excellent, thank you. I'll give it a try and report back how it goes.
-Bill
comments.author: adafruit

comments.text: The new model to holed the Circuit Playground worked out great, thank you. I submitted my pictures of it as a make. The lantern itself will be another 20 hours or so of printing :-)
comments.author: TinWhiskerz

comments.text:
I have the shade (printed in white PLA) and lantern bottom printed out. (Top is printing as we speak)
Two thoughts related to this project:
1.) Would be neat to have a circular ring/top plate on top of your electronics enclosure to not allow any light from the circuit playground to be seen from looking down at the lantern. (So it would be a circular disk with a lip on the bottom and holes on it to keep it aligned with your base that holds the electronics) and have a flat surface that covers the places where the light is escaping between the electronics base and base of the lantern). It's something I could make as a remix but might take me a while to get to it.
2.) Would be neat to have a variant of the lamp shade that could be spiralized (I know that is really from the model by someone else) but that black magic setting likely would make the walls a tiny bit thinner and let more light come through. I'm thinking about reprinting a shade in clear nGen to see how it compares to the white PLA.
Thanks for the fun project idea. I'll post more pics one I finish the lantern.

comments.text: I would be very interested in the durablity of this piece. Could you let us know if it breaks? Is that PLA? Seems like it might be prone to breaking because of the direction of the print and the layer lines crossing the handle. comments.text:
Hi - that is ABS (5 shells! 25% infill .3 micron layer height).
I tried to break it with all my might after printing. Then we spent about 3hrs shoveling wet sloppy snow with no breakage.
Agreed that changing orientation would make for better strength but me and "supports" don't get along (same goes for it's friend "rafts". So knowing this would print standing up was a win for me.

title: G2 Skate Bearing 22x7x 8mm shaft GT2 Idler Pulley

description.text:
This is a drop in idler pulley that fits a GT2 timing belt and holds a 608 bearing with the dimensions 22x7x 8mm bore. It is designed to fit an 8 mm smooth rod. I would recommend tapping a hole in the rod or grinding out a flat to place 2 set screws on the 8mm rod so that it does not shift around. Put in one of those tiny hex cap headless screws with a drop of crazy glue, aka cyanoacrylate, and you are good to go! This also fits an imperial 5/16th rod, but with a looser fit.

description.text:
I decided that My ScrollBot From Pimoroni Deserved a Body, so knocked this one up in Fusion360.

The ScrollBot will fit unaltered into the stands on the back of the body to hold the head above his shoulders and at a flatter angle. This will allow him to be sat on a high shelf but still see his "Mouth" clearly

I thought that more ScrollBots may like a body so am uploading the file so we can all print them. :-)
I have also uploaded the Fusion360 File for if you would like to remix him.

I printed Scrolly in True Orange PolyMax PLA which was a nice colour match for his face, and used a bed temp of 60 with a skirt and a nozzle temp of 210 C, though you will want to tweek those settings for your setup and flavor of filament
I made Scrolly in Fusion360 so have uploaded the file so you can Remix him. i look forward to seeing what may come from him.

description.text: I found this beautiful high resolution scan of the head of Venus de Milo at http://www.deskproto.com/support-videos/videos-venus.php and was quite surprised that it hadn't found its way onto Thingiverse yet. Their website does state that the STL file may not be offered for downloading (thanks to TheRuttMeister for pointing this out) so I have removed my derivative file and recommend that you go to their site and download it directly from them or use this link http://www.deskproto.com/files/venus-stl.zip

Don't download the dummy file from here. Instead go and get the original from the DeskProto site.
Resize the STL file using a program like NetFabb or Blender and slice the bottom off to give it a flat base.

description.text:
A wearable helmet inspired by Magneto from X-Men: Days of Future Past. I wore this to Comic Con Denver 2017, and it survived all 3 days without breaking.

Sizing Table (Estimates):
Measure the circumference of your head around your brow (see the included picture), and consult the scaling percentage chart below. These are based on estimates I generated in my modeling software.

Brow Circumference (in mm) Scale Factor (all dimensions)
765 mm 1.25x
734 mm 1.20x
704 mm 1.15x
673 mm 1.10x
643 mm 1.05x
612 mm 1.0x
582 mm 0.95x
551 mm 0.90x
520 mm 0.85x
490 mm 0.80x
459 mm 0.75x

NOTES:
1) I have a fairly large head, so the helmet maybe big on you if you print it as it is. If you scale it let me know your brim circumference and scale factor so I can fill out the table above.
2) Depending on your print bed size (and helmet size) you may want to split the helmet into multiple pieces. I had to split mine into 4 separate pieces. A bit of Bondo will fix this problem easily.
3) Leave some space between your head and the interior of the helmet. You'll want to attach foam pads on the inside to make it more wearable, and you'll want adequate space (~5mm) to pull you head out of the helmet. If you follow my scaling guide, I believe this space should be adequate.

Thanks to lehthanis for use of his human head model that allowed me to design this:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758647
Its his model featured as the head model in the pictures. This file does not include the head model.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I had to print this in 4 pieces on my printer.

Assembly / Creation of the Helmet

Clean up all support material. Attach the pieces you printed together with Bondo. For texture (and to get that hand crafted / weathered look), apply a rough layer of Bondo to the exterior of the helmet. Make sure all seams between printed pieces are covered and blend in. After the Bondo has dried, sand down to desired texture level. If necessary, use a Dremel tool to bring back the emphasis on the detail parts. Attach foam pieces on the inside to increase stability of helmet, and make it more wearable.

I used some of the metallic patio furniture paints from Home Depot to get the colors here. To give it that more Comic Book Villain feel, I went back and traced the edges of the details in black.

Bondo applied to the helmet after assembly. Minor sanding performed.
Rhino 5

Play a game of mini mini golf. With a hill, tunnels and challenge, this is actually pretty fun. Your goal is to hit the ball (or flick it) into the ring. The best way to play is if it falls onto the lower levels, you can keep trying but if you hit off of the 3d printed part you start over. You can use golf club or your fingers. This is my first project btw, so if it's like, really awful let me know. Thanks.

I used XYZmaker and XYZware, but honestly, it works with about everything.

This was inspired by my brother liking mini golf a lot and how he thought it would be cool to 3D print a golf course.

description.text:
This kit consists of a wheel and a connection post for Kitchenaid dishwashers. Due to the high temperature and strong abrasives found in dishwashers it's important to choose your materials carefully. I printed mine in DruckWege clear resin on my YHD-101, but in theory nylon from an FDM printer should hold up as well.

The wheel is easy - just print and go. The connection post is a little tougher, the final printed diameter of the post's tip needs to be 7.8-7.9mm. The part as designed is 8.0mm and on my YHD-101 comes out to the correct size due to resin shrinkage, but this may require tweaking for other printers, other resins, or other printing methods.

This is a rear case for the TBS RaceTracker. I received a replacement PCB board and wanted to use the old PCB for LED gates but didn't want to leave it exposed to the elements.

This case is almost the exact same size as the original and you can install another 18650 battery in the case. I recommend that you use some foam or 2 way tape to insulate and secure the battery.

I used 4 dabs of hot glue to old the PDB to the front case. It is also designed so you can still use the usb port to charge the battery.

description.text: Don't print this thing by itself! This is a boolean punch, a modular functionality. It creates a negative space which adds a function to another object. In this case it turns your object into an led light. See Glowda:the glowing Yoda http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:241884 for an example Use Blender or a similar program to boolean this shape out of another object. Then insert an LED and a 2032 lithium battery. You may need to play with bending the wires to make good contact. Check your polarity before pushing the battery all the way in. More details on my blog: http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com

description.text:
Herakles from Hadrians villa in Tivoli Skopas. Greek, mid 4th century BC, Rome copy, Malibu, J.p. Getty Museum. The Royal Cast Collection (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now ReMake) from AutoDesk.

Heracles , born Alcaeus or Alcides, was a divine hero in Greek mythology, the son of Zeus and Alcmene, foster son of Amphitryon and great-grandson and half-brother (as they are both sired by the god Zeus) of Perseus. He was the greatest of the Greek heroes, a paragon of masculinity, the ancestor of royal clans who claimed to be Heracleidae. In Rome and the modern West, he is known as Hercules. Many popular stories were told of his life, the most famous being The Twelve Labours of Heracles.

For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

This is the simplified DIY version of a magnetic endstop. Instead of using a hall effect sensor and some logic, it uses a hall switch. So the board is much simpler.
PLUS - it has a control LED. Cheap-O in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=smRay_nAUWA Update: Improved STL for super slim design.

Get a TLE4905 (for about 1 EUR), 2 x 4.7 nF caps, a LED, 1.2kOhm and 3.3kOhm resistors and a tiny piece of strip board pcb (I needed 7 strips by 5 holes).
Drill 2 3 mm holes.
Solder according to photos and schematic.
Mount.
Glue a magnet to your axis (I used 3 mm neodym cubes). enjoy your cheap and accurate endstop.

title: Elder Wand_with Core_Edited
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After a request I enlarged the Elder Wand found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1866346

Hopefully this version should print without splits in the top of the middle section, and should struggle less with the very tip. I have ensured that it will work with the original core size (so no need to re-print your core if you already have one). However, I haven't had an opportunity to print this one out but I hope it should be an improvement.

The background behind this project was ...

This all started when I wanted to print the fantastic wand that was designed by jakereeves but wanted to print it broken up vertically, and rather than having to stick the pieces together, create some sort of screw fitting........but what is a wand without a core?!

In true Wizarding World fashion, I have created a wand where you can print whichever core has picked you! Why not try....

A cherry red dragon heart string
A pearly white unicorn hair
A golden phoenix tail feather

This wand is printed in 4 parts. A handle, a central section, a tip and a core. The core is used to hold all the other 3 sections together, and remains hidden inside the wand. The core can only be revealed by unscrewing the tip and removing the central section.

WARNING: Always ask permission of the wand owner before revealing the core - it is magical after all and can be temperamental. Unfortunately, we can not be held responsible for any spells back-firing.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The wand_core will need to be printed with a raft, the other files can be printed without.

Assembling Your Wand
  1. Screw the core into the handle
  2. Slide the central section over the core
  3. Screw the tip on to the end of the core

description.text:
Spool hub spindle in 70 mm, 75 mm, 90 mm and 105 mm overall lengths. Designed for 2x 608 bearings (22 mm OD bearing). 13mm diameter hole through the spindle. Spindle and cap are self centering for 40-60 mm diameter spool openings.

The 70 mm spindle works well for eSun, 75 mm spindle for Hatchbox and 105 mm for Prusa sourced spools. The cap is interchangable. The washer is to maintain separation of the spools for optimal spinning.

If you're unsure which spindle to print, either measure the width of your spool for approx sizing or 1) print the cap and test fit to the spool center 2) measure the distance the cap extends from the side of the spool 3) double that and add to the spool width to determine minimum spindle length.

In my filament dry box I use a 5/16" threaded rod (~M8 rod) with these hubs, my 608 BB bearings (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2418959), printed washers and rod clips.

Design inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2135132. Easy to make in Fusion 360.

title: Soft serve ice cream machine nozzles

description.text:
After getting an ice cream machine, I couldn't find any suitable (or cheap) nozzles, so I made a few of my own. These are designed for the TermoNord 2.0M, but should probably fit most common ice cream machines.

There are currently three different nozzles. A blender file is included to easily create new variations of the nozzle. Feel free to send me nozzles you created and I can include them in this package. I will also try to add more over time.

Note that I have only tried printing these in TPU, as they are pushed in place and then snaps to the machine. This probably requires a flexible filament, but I have not tried with PLA / ABS. If you try, please let me know of your progress.

Enjoy your summer and ice creams! :)

How to make your own nozzle

Open the blender file. Create an object that looks like the hole you want, place it at position 0,0,0 and hide it. Select the nozzle and change the object in the boolean operation to your hole. Select the nozzle object, pick File -> Export -> STL from the menu. Tick "Selection only" and "Apply modifiers" checkboxes and export your STL file.

author: stingray454

description.text:
Holders for mounting on pegboard. Also an exercise to bring up my CAD/FDM printing vocabulary. As the first picture hints, going through a series of iterations to work out what works (or not).

So far...

  • Holder for Screwdrivers - posted separately: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2405739
  • Arms - 4in and 6in arms (used for hand saws and clamps), and 6in "strong" arms.
  • Holder for wood rasp.
  • Holder for metal snips.

See also:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2405739

Major goals (as the above):

  • Use with common (in the USA) pegboard with 1/4" holes on 1" spacing.
  • Can use common drywall screws (or any "wood" screw with ~4mm outside diameter).
  • Does not damage the pegboard.
  • Anchors should be somewhat re-usable.
  • Very solid mount with screw/anchor together.

Minor goals:

  • Printable without supports (where practical).
  • Uses minimal plastic for the needed strength.
  • Strong as possible with the material used. (Slightly redundant with the prior.)

Note in particular the bit you do not see - the bits of plastic that act as anchors. I wanted something much stronger than a plastic peg. The majority of the load is taken by the metal screw. The bit of plastic that acts as anchor compresses against the pegboard hole and the back of the pegboard, just enough to hold the screw in place. The result is solid and strong.

If you end up moving around things a lot before settling on final arrangement, you might wear out some anchors, and have to print a few replacements. As the anchors take relatively little time to print (15-20 minutes in my case), this is acceptable.

Note that at present this design for arms is entirely suitable for lighter objects, but not as good as I would like for heavier objects. The problem is that FDM prints are stronger with than across the "grain" of the print. In the current print (when printed with the arm horizontal), the arm is reasonably strong, but the base above the arm is a bit weak.

If you print the arms in the same orientation as when on the pegboard, you do not need support structure. If you print the arms sideways, you must use support structures, but the base of the arm is stronger (due to the "grain" of the plastic).

Designed in Onshape

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f305ddb33dccf9b8f590d508/w/d399532ef666f6847449ecdc/e/3956a19a85e4e00e11748bc7

Anchor
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f017467ad40ef4eefc400eb7/w/65bb1f743d8719d747c7f112/e/a028dfbfbf29e7c99e1124e3

title: 608 Bearing BB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet another 608 bearing. 11 4.5mm (.177 caliber) BB's fit inside. After 5-6 BB's are added, align and use the little channels to force in the rest. I use the the butt of a screwdriver or large pliers to force them in part way then rotate the bearing to seat the BB in the raceway. Naming convention: raceway_offset-3.85mm_raceway-InnerRadius-2.3mm_OuterRadius-2.275mm

Relatively tight clearances but very free and smooth movement. I've used them in fidget spinners and my spool hubs.

Update: I tried printing 608_Bearing_BB_3.85_2.3_2.25 at .1 mm layer height but 25% of them came out too tight and I had to loosen them up with a high speed drill so I replaced it with 608_Bearing_BB_3.85_2.275_2.275 and printed at .15 mm layer height with .25 mm and .40 nozzles. Also, inspect the raceways for defects or extra filament.
Added another bearing with slightly looser tolerances: 608_Bearing_BB_3.90_2.3_2.25 and the various iteration parts so you can mix and match so long as the raceway offset is the same.

description.text:
This is my attempt to make the gourd type purple martin birdhouse.
Using the screw and lid from thing:84

The following is from:
https://www.purplemartin.org/purple-martins/history/59/tradition-shift/

Purple Martins are considered secondary cavity nesters—they do not excavate their own cavities such as woodpeckers. Instead they use cavities that are already created, either by other animals or in natural cavities of cliffs and rock formations. Traditionally Purple Martins nested in natural cavities such as old woodpecker holes, on rock ledges, or in dead trees. However, thousands of years ago, people began providing man-made housing for the Purple Martins in the form of dried, hollow gourds. Over time, the successful nesting of martins in these man-made homes, paired with the decline of natural cavities, led to a complete behavior shift within the eastern species.

Lets make more homes for the Purple Martin!

Feedback / corrections to the model are much appreciated.

description.text:
Fits the Cuisinart CRC-400 rice cooker. This is meant to replace the plastic insert on the lid, which can crack (mine lasted eight years).

Pull the screw--it has probably fallen out by now which is why you're here. You'll need a Philips screwdriver and some torque; this part doesn't have threads. It works via sheer force on the screw's own threads. Consequently, lots of twist will be required to get the screw into the part.

Having used the rice cooker normally on July 22, 2017 I can report that for at least one use, this part held together. (I believed it was possible heat/moisture from the cooker might cause this part to fail during cooking--this did not happen).

In addition, while this part does not come in direct contact with food during cooking, using plastic not certified as food-safe is done at your own risk.

I did not make the 3d model. I only modified it to be able to 3d print. Original head/bust model derived from the video game "Batman: Arkham Asylum". Full body model extracted and provided by Nobby76. This is for personal use only and may not be used for profit. Please note that the ears are very pointy so I'm not responsible if you poke an eye out. Keep out of the reach of children.
EDIT: I would slow the print down by 50% when it reaches the ears. It will go back and fourth so fast that it does not allow to plastic to cool.

title: MFOS Noise Toaster Synthesizer Case and Panel

description.text:
This is a case and front panel for the Music From Outer Space "Noise Toaster", as featured in the book Make: Analog Synthesizers and at http://musicfromouterspace.com/. This project is an absolute blast to put together and play with. The MFOS website does a much better job of explaining this little DIY Synthesizer, but I will quote Ray Wilson from his website: "The MFOS NOISE TOASTER squeezes more fun out of a nine volt battery than you ever thought possible".

I put together the electronics on a stripboard, but if I were to do it again, I would pick up a PCB from the MFOS website and saved myself hours of debugging. Ray does a great job on his web site and book with the schematics and parts list so the project goes together very quickly.

The front panel includes raised text, and so must be printed with two colors. Most slicers include a "pause at height" plugin, which will move the hot end out of the way and allow you to switch filaments. The panel is 3mm thick, and the text 0.5 mm, so add the command to pause after you finish printing the 3mm layer. (One tip: If you find that your printer is disabling the stepper motors after pausing, you may need to insert M84 S0 at the start of the G-Code. I did.)

The case includes a space for a 1" diameter speaker (0.5W, 8 Ohm). I used a hot glue gun to mount the speaker. The case also includes a 9V battery compartment.

The case is held together with M3 bolts, with slots to hold the nuts on the other side. The nuts should stay in place on their own, but if you wish to make sure they don't fall out when attaching the panel or battery cover, a small drop of epoxy will keep them in place permanently.

The entire case can be printed without supports. There are a few bridges and small overhangs, but my printer was able to handle them just fine. I printed this with 0.25mm layers and 25% infill.

I've included a SketchUp file in case any modifications are required. This design should be compatible with the MFOS PCB, so as long as you buy a 1" diameter speaker, no modifications should be needed.

description.text:
I've added three more variations, one slightly smaller, one with a curved bottom and one with a chamfered bottom (print the last two upside down)

A very quick and simple fix for damaged laptop screw inserts.
Sometimes when a laptop is dropped, the brass insert breaks the small plastic housings,
making it impossible to screw the laptop case back together.

These have a 3.8mm internal hole.
Just squeeze the original brass part into the hole with a vice and glue in position in the laptop very carefully and accurately

These are flat bottomed and may only fit in certain positions.
You need to remove the original damaged plastic to allow this part to fit on a flat surface.
If the part needs to be thicker than 2.8mm then just scale up in the z direction,
This was made to fit typical laptop brass inserts and may not fit all, but they only take a minute or so to print and you can scale up or down if needed.

0.2mm layer height 1.2mm walls 100% infill

Here is the sliding part commonly used for the chest straps on hiking rucksacks.  I lost one as the slider rail wasn't properly terminated on my rucksack. The internal diameter is 3.7mm, the same as the slider on the opposite strap. This corresponds to a rail of about 3.2mm diameter (as measured from my rucksack.
I printed this part successfully on a RRP Ormerod 3D printer, with the cylinder pointing upright and with an 8mm brim holding it secure.

description.text:
This is an eavestrough outlet for 2x3 inch downspout piping. I printed it with PETG so that it can withstand high heat from the sun over time.

There are no screw holes. I was able to screw into it just fine with metal screws used for installing downspouts and eavestroughs. I added a dollop of silicone to the flange portion to prevent any leaking around the downspout.

I've included the Fusion360 project export so that others may modify it if required.

I have a Maker Select and I use AzzA's Z-brace mod. Every time I work around the printer or when removing prints I always seem to move/slide the printer around the table it sits on. Got tired of that so I made these simple table brackets.

title: 90 Degree air nozzle and mounting brackets for Hovercraft

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hchSi69IHgN
I am making a hovercraft as a platform for my Samsung Gear 360 camera (less bounce when moving over rough terrain than a wheel-driven RC platform).

I needed some air-nozzles to capture some of the lift-air from under the hovercraft to use as propulsion for forward movement as well as steering the craft. I came up with this.

There is a tab on top of the nozzle I will use to mount connecting arms so I can gang them all together (don't know yet how many I need/can get away with stealing lift-air) and then use one servo to steer with. I control speed of lift fans to control forward speed.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Owning a split table that pulls apart to make it bigger (by inserting a center piece), I have been frustrated by it coming apart by itself with the least amount of pressure applied to one side of it, exposing a gap in the middle. I searched Thingiverse for locking clasps but was unable to find one I felt was appropriate. So I designed this myself from scratch.

You mount each piece so that the clasp can turn (it can be quite firm) thus preventing the table from coming accidentally apart. I built 2 of these, one for each side of the table.

I used T-Glase for the base, and Nylon Bridge for the moving clasp. The Nylon has a little bit of flex and is quite slippery against the T-Glase allowing for little friction when sliding the parts together. Unless you open and close the clasp dozens of times a day, I am sure any material would work equaly well as wear due to friction should be low.

This really needs to be fairly solid as it is subject to some force.

I printed the clasp upside down as my printer has a tendancy to warp nylon for the first 2-3 mm on the print bed and then prints it perfectly. As the bottom of the clasp really needs to be perfectly flat it was easier to flip it by 180 degrees and print the bottom on top to ensure it stays level. This was only needed for Nylon. PLA and ABS prints fine without warping, so no flipping required.
Make sure the parts fit smoothly together before mounting them on the underside of the table.

Being a complete novice, only having purchased my first 3D printer a couple of weeks ago and having no 3D experience at all I am currently using TinkerCad for designing my 3D objects as it has an extremely small learning curve.

The parts were put together from a whole bunch of boxes and cylinders.

title: Maker Box 1.75 Filament Spool with Inserts

description.text:
This my version of a sample filament spool for Maker Box that combines what I liked from some other spools, and adds a design element of my own. This is the fifth (and hopefully final) revision I've gone through.

The main components of this spool are printed in two parts, with a large threaded center that allows them to be securely connected, and later re-used. You can lay the filament sample in one half (the spool bottom), anchor one end in the provided 60 degree hole (in either direction), and lock it in place with the top half of the spool. Then the filament can be hand-tightened, or (my preference) used to unspool onto a second filament holder, which I've shown in an example picture. The design is sized to easily slip back into the zip-lock bags that the filament samples come in, with a bit of room to spare. There are holes around the outer rim to anchor the end of the sample, which should be snug for 1.75mm filament.

I created two sizes of inserts that snap into the center of each half of the spool to make it fit different spool holders more closely. One is 25mm in diameter, the other is 40mm in diameter. The spool can be used without the inserts at all. If anyone needs a different size, let me know and I can add others.

I suggest printing in PETG or some material that has a bit more flex than straight PLA. PLA might work, but could crack more easily over time on the arms of the inserts or the outer ring when pressure is applied. ABS might also work, but I haven't tried it, and don't know if shrinking would cause any issues. All pieces print without supports, and shouldn't need any brim or raft.

The threads typically come out best with proper cooling around the print head. Some stringing could occur otherwise. Even if it does, there should be enough clearance between the threads in the two parts to still fit together.

Design ideas borrowed:

  • Small anchor holes around perimeter and in base to anchor the filament: Dingoboy71
  • Screw-together column design to separate the spool: Dingoboy71
  • Ability to fit sample spool back into original bags: jlarsenwy

Note: This is designed to be used with Maker Box samples, but the samples themselves may not contain enough plastic to print these!

remixed_from.title: Pinstax - the Instant Pinhole camera project

title: terraPinstax Wide Pinhole Camera Body
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This project came to life when a friend requested that I design a pinhole camera body around an instant film back, made by Lomography for the Belair Lomo camera. She wanted a wide angle of view, but otherwise gave me free rein. I settled on a 35mm "focal length", and after some math worked out that the aperture should be 0.26 mm in diameter. This gives a F Stop of f/136 in the middle, but shooting this at f/165 is a nice compromise between an overexposed center or dark, dark corners.

The Lomography instant film back (User's Guide) uses Fujifilm Instax Wide film packs, a popular and vibrant instant film stock. The film is available in a variety of formats, and a variety of cameras are available from Fujifilm and other manufacturers. Unlike Fujifilm/Fujichrome professional film stocks, technical data is not provided for reciprocity failure (RF) behavior. I am testing the film with the goal of a reliable RF curve, but I am still in the early stages. Experimentation continues.

Previously, I designed a pinhole camera body to work with the Lomography Instax Mini film back for the Diana F+ camera. I wrote a bit about my struggles getting the film to work in a pinhole camera on [Hackaday}(https://hackaday.io/project/211-pinstax-3d-printed-instant-pinhole-camera).

Film specifications (wikipedia)
Film speed ISO 800/30°
Colour temperature Daylight type (5500K)
Resolving power 10 lines/mm
Photos per pack 10
Film size
(W×H) 108 mm × 86 mm (4.3 in × 3.4 in)
Image size
(W×H) 99 mm × 62 mm (3.9 in × 2.4 in)
Aspect ratio 1.618:1
Film pack size
(W×H×D) 115 mm × 92 mm × 20 mm (4.5 in × 3.6 in × 0.8 in)

The film is fast (ISO 800), but my testing reveals that exposures compensated for RF are much longer than many slower film stocks. Shooting the film outside the designed exposure parameters (i.e. slow pinhole shots) also causes a blue color shift. Embrace this, play with this. Colored filters may be able to correct for this, but don't expect accurate color rendering.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license, with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm / layer

Infill:

50%+ for strength and opacity

Notes:

First and foremost, USE OPAQUE FILAMENT. ABS is fine, but PLA is prone to translucence. If unsure, use this OPACITY TOOL to assess the opacity of your filament. I maintain a list of tested PLA filaments and their opacity on that Thing page; If you find another opaque PLA, please share in the comments.

I am currently having great results with eSun Pro Black PLA.

Clean-Up

BODY:
Hot off the print bed (OK, wait for it to cool, so it doesn't warp), you may have fine strings inside the camera body which will be visible in your photographs. You can pluck these out with tweezers, trim them with a blade, or use a wire brush. These are all methods I have used with success. However, I have been using propane to eradicate any stray strands inside my camera bodies (or on a plate of parts) for several years, and works fantastically.

I fill the space with propane from a source like a lighter or a plumbers's torch - NOT LIT! Propane is heavier than air and will displace most of the air in the camera body. Working quickly, MOVE THE TORCH AWAY and, with a lighter, ignite the propane inside the camera body. The propane will burn quickly and any strands will be consumed or melted into tiny balls. I typically do this several times, and have acquired a reliable technique. A sufficiently-thick 3D printed part will not get hot enough to soften or warp, but I still allow it to cool before handling. If necessary, any residue can be removed with a small wire brush, or even your finger.

DISCLAIMER: Your mileage may vary. Propane is dangerous. I AM NOT telling you to do this; I am telling you what I do. If you burn down your house, it's not my fault. If you burn yourself, it's not my fault. If you ruin your 3D printed object, it's not my fault. I could go on, but any bad stuff that happens because you follow these instructions is not my fault. Be safe.

Moving on, if you print on painter's tape (wonderful stuff), you may have tiny ridges, from the tape seams, on the bottom surface of your parts. I use a razor scraper to shave these off. A sharp razor will take these off nicely. Again, razors are dangerous. See disclaimer, above.

Bore out the shutter bolt hole with a 3mm or 1/8 inch drill bit. Also clear out the holes for the fixing bolts at each end of the body with the same drill bit.

SHUTTER:
The shutter prints upside down, and the top surface will rotate against the camera body when opening and closing the shutter. This surface must be flat for smooth shutter action. I use a coarse mill file to take off any surface irregularities, being careful not to damage the nub that indexes the angular position of the open shutter. Also, the countersink for the shutter bolt may need to be cleaned / reamed for smooth shutter operation. I use a handheld countersink bit for this. It's worth mentioning that metric fasteners meant for countersunk applications have a 90° chamfer angle, but the angle may vary for other fasteners (and by extension, countersink bits)

Depending on how well your printer handles overhangs, there may be other areas that need some finishing before assembly.

PLA can be kind of shiny, so I typically apply a flat black paint to inside surfaces that may cause reflections and ghosting. After assembly, I paint the shutter nut and bold inside the camera body with flat black paint also. It's probably not necessary.

Assembly

You will need the following hardware:

1 - 0.26mm pinhole (making a pinhole is not difficult, but it warrants practice. THIS is how I do it.)

1 - M3 countersunk (phillips or socket) bolt, 10mm length (shutter)
1 - M3 locknut (shutter)
1 - M3 washer (shutter - optional)
2 - M3 socket head bolt, 16mm length (body fixing bolt)
2 - M3 nuts (for fixing bolts, inserted into nut traps in mounting dogs)

Cyanoacrylate or Super glue

Sharpie or similar
Gaffer or Electrical tape

Refer to the CAD renders that illustrate assembly
PINHOLE:
Examine your pinhole; determine which side you want visible from outside the camera. Blacken the BACK of the pinhole (probably unnecessary). I use a Sharpie. Make sure you don't fill the hole with ink, and clean any ink from the FRONT side of the pinhole with a swipe of rubbing alcohol. I cut a small diamond from the tape and carefully center the (BACK side of the) pinhole in the cutout. Again, carefully, I center the (FRONT side of the) pinhole in the opening in the camera body, FROM THE INSIDE. I design my cameras with a little wiggle room here, but if your pinhole is too far off-center, you risk having the edges of the opening and/or shutter blocking light to your film. Go slowly, take your time. People will want to see the pinhole when you show off your camera and you want it centered nicely.

SHUTTER:
The shutter disc is held onto the camera body with the 10mm-long M3 countersunk bolt, fastened with the locknut and washer. It mounts with the countersink on the outside, with the nub inserted into the arced trough in the face of the camera. Adjust the tightness of the bolt to allow for smooth rotation. If it binds at all, something's catching - disassemble and correct. Play with the shutter a bit more - it may become a bit looser. Tighten if necessary.

When you're satisfied with the shutter, the round baffle is glued on the face of the camera. This part not only looks super-cool, but, more importantly, it prevents light from worming its way under the shutter disc and slowly fogging your film. Apply a THIN bead of super glue on the back (bottom) side of the baffle. You don't want to get any glue on your shutter disc. I use a bamboo skewer to prevent big, ugly blops of glue. Gently lower the baffle onto the camera face, around and outside the shutter disc. There is a tiny bit of play in the fit, and, if you work quickly, you can position the baffle to be perfectly centered before the glue begins to set. Clamp with your fingers until you are positive it won't move accidentally.

MOUNTING THE CAMERA TO THE FILM BACK:
The film back was designed for a snap-fit onto the body of the Lomography Belair camera, and has a pair of recesses on each side for a sliding lock mechanism. The dogs (arched pieces with feet) fit into these recesses; they will only fit one way and are identical. The camera body slides over the dogs and is fastened with the 16mm-long M3 socket head bolts. The dogs have a trap that fits an M3 nut. The best way I have found to mount the camera body to the film back is as follows:

  1. Insert the dogs into the recesses at the outside edge of the film back.
    2 Slide the camera body OVER the dogs, into the slot at each end of the body.
  2. STOP when the nut trap is just below the outside edge of the camera body on each side
  3. Insert an M3 nut into the nut trap and slide body several mm over the nut to hold it captive. The nut will fit into a space in the slot. Do one side, then the other.
  4. Fully seat the body onto the film back with the dogs and nuts in place.
  5. Insert the M3 16mm socket nuts into the holes on the edge of the camera body and tighten firmly. Do not overtighten - you could damage the 3D printed parts or the film back!

Read the User's Guide and load film back.

Shoot some pinhole photographs!

Share your 3Dprinted terraPinstax Pinhole Camera build and your photos on Thingiverse!

description.text:
Overview
This is a dashboard upgrade for the epic RPG boardgame Sword & Sorcery, designed by Gremlin Project and distributed by Ares Games.

The playing cards and cardboard pieces from game can start to spread out and take up a lot of table space, plus there is no way to track actual stats in the game. For example, if your hero has a starting backpack size of 3 and is holding two items that give +2 backpack size, what is your actual carrying limit? Instead of doing the math each time, I prefer to record actual current values (it's 5). The same goes for Armor and Health, multiple items and powers can modify the Soulgem values. I like having these crucial values readable at a glance.

The dashboards have seven sets of holes for pegs for you to track stats: five holes (4), seven holes (1), 10 holes (1), and 12 holes (1). I use them to track Soulrank, Backpack size, Armor/Defense points, Combat actions, regular actions, and Health, but the sets are not labeled so you are free to use them for whatever you want.

There is also a slider at the bottom of the center console that can be used to mark Hero activation, instead of flipping the cardboard gem token, which I found to be too fiddly.

The Backpack and Powers pieces attach to the center console via OpenLock clips, which can be downloaded from here.

This thing was designed on Autodesk Fusion 360 as a project both for fun and for teaching myself more of Fusion 360.

If you do not want to print your own pegs or just don't care for the ones I designed, then these ones will work as well.

Changelog:

* v1.0 Initial upload
* v1.1 Increased peg hole diameter to 4.6mm
* v1.2 Added integral supports to Backpack and Powers Openlock receptacle
* v1.3 Removed extraneous fillet from Openlock supports in Backpack
* Added a combined main console that prints as one piece.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100-200um

Notes:
  • No supports are needed for any of the pieces.
  • I printed the pegs at 100% infill with 100um layer height to make them solid and sturdy.
  • I printed all the other pieces at 10% infill with 200um layer height.
  • Be sure to orient the activation gem so it can be printed without supports (you might need to flip it 180 degrees in either the X or Y axis in your slicer).
  • Backpack and Powers have internal supports in the OpenLock receptacle which you knock out.
  • The center console has two versions: a two-piece set that requires no supports, and a single piece set that has built-in supports for the OpenLock receptacles and Activation Gem slot. Use a flat-bladed screwdriver to knock off the built-in supports. It's okay if a little bit remains in the gem slot--they add a cool zipper sound when sliding the Activation Gem.

author: Thor24Thor

description.text:
DIY Replacement Filter Cartridge.

Darn Pool and spa filters are expensive. So I created these. Printed in 2 halves, fill with generic pillow filler or "poly fill", place both halves together and insert into your pool/spa filter holder. There you have it a cheap replacement for those expensive pool filters.

The filter this replaces is 127 mm diameter with a 54 mm hole and 13.25" (336.55 mm) tall.
You can print this if you can print something 170 mm tall.

Some of the numbers this filter are know as are :
FC-2375
PRB25
C-4326

YOU MUST PRINT IN ABS or the cage will degrade in 1-3 months.
DO NOT try to use PLA.

Print with solid base on bed and turn on supports.

I printed it and due to the retraction and slow printing (it took 26 hours to print), It didn't meet my expectations. I will be modifying the design to make it stronger.

UPDATE: New design, thicker, MUCH stronger.
This is the craziest recipe for print settings ever!, but WOW it printed incredible!

Printed in ABS using

Simplify3D users download the .fff profile to print from
[ABS.8 (Pergo FilterPrint).fff] profile that I printed with
.8 mm nozzle
270C (Yes thats right 270c)
.5 mm Layer height (Yes software will complain of this layer height with .8 mm nozzle)
! NO Extraction ! (The stringing helped the print with supports)
30 mm /sec print speed Print was about 8 hrs. 231.5 g of filament
100% infill
3 shells (top bottom & sides)
85c Bed temp, Layer 10-75c Layer 20-70c
!! Supports are ONLY ever other layer!!
!Supports with a .8 mm nozzle every layer cause all kinds of problems!

Printed on a Robo3D R1+ (e3Dv6 hotend) WITH NO PLASTIC or Heat cage!
using the 270c I got a perfect print in open air and it's very strong.

Quite a cleanup job popping out all those supports. But mission success, I have a filter in my spa now. Verify one layer of the base before committing the full print. My 54 mm hole didn't fit on the 54 mm spindle. My printer needed calibration to get the size right. To give others some flex room I changed the inner hole to 56 mm in the model. The original filters are slight rubber so they stretch a bit around the spindle, something that ABS can't do.
I'm Printing my 2nd filter now. My spa uses 2 filters, so I have to print 4 of these.

print_settings.Notes:: Rotate the piece upside down for print.

title: Penny Bottle Opener with Embedded Magnet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My take on the penny bottle opener. There is a space for an optional 0.25" long, 0.25" diameter (6.4 x 6.4 mm) cylindrical magnet just above the cap which will allow the opener to retain the cap. Will open bottles with or without the magnet.

If you do want to embed a magnet, inspect the layers and find the last layer before the magnet space is covered and insert a pause at the end of that layer in your g-code. I've used the following with a MP Mini:
M401 ; store position
M600 0 0 0 0 0 ; pause
M402 ; restore position

The above may not work for all printers but many people have experimented with embedding objects in prints so you should find plenty of examples online.

If you'd like a version for your country's most convenient currency, shoot me a message with the dimensions in millimeters and I'll try to make an updated model (no guarantees on delivery time!).

Lastly, the penny insertion is an interference fit - you may have to force it but it should not be loose. I have printed several dozen instances on multiple printers and have not run into fit issues. If you have fit issues with the penny, there's a good chance something is off in your print settings or printer calibration. Likewise for strength if you follow my suggestions for infill. Please adjust accordingly before commenting.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm or less

Infill:

40% or greater

Notes:

Use three perimeter shells. There are only a couple stress concentrations in this design and they will be solid with three shells so infill can be surprisingly light. You can get away with as little as 20% honeycomb infill but I strongly suggest 40% or greater. Honeycomb or star infill patterns are best but rectilinear will probably work at 50% or greater.

I have only printed this in PLA - would love to hear how other materials work. Considering a TPU print as a joke.

title: Hand Drive Wheelchair Attachment (non-geared)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We were given the challenge to hack a wheelchair and make it better. Through research, we discovered that lever-powered wheelchairs were proven to be a better physical motion for the user. We also discovered how expensive they were—anywhere from $2,000-$10,000.

Instead of redesigning the wheelchair, we came up with the idea of a Hand Drive wheelchair attachment that could make lever-powered wheelchairs more accessible to everyday users. Our attachment is almost entirely 3D printable, it’s completely open source, and costs only $40 to make, which is less than 1% of the cost of its competitors on the market.

The Hand Drive wheelchair attachment can be attached to any wheelchair and allows it to be powered in a rowing motion. This motion is better for your back, as it uses bigger muscle groups, and it keeps your hands cleaner. Because of our price point and the adaptability of the Hand Drive, all wheelchair users now have access to a lever-powered wheelchair.

Hand Drive Homepage and Build Instructions

https://hackaday.io/project/7221-hand-drive

https://cambridge.nuvustudio.com/studios/hand-drive#tab-info-url

I was low on 608 bearings and wanted to use coins as the counter weights. It came out wonderful, and the SCAD file was easy to customize.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1775765

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1775765
Using the following options:

I like to buy the small sample packs of 1.75 ABS filament on Ebay.
50 grams - 12 meters, so they are pretty small.
I always have a hard time feeding them into my printer.
I came across this spool and remixed it.
I put a huge 50mm hub on it. I copied the hole size from the 1 kg spools. That way it will fit onto my hub on my printer. I shortened up the arms quite a bit. I can flex a short roll of filament right over the u shaped arms. I glued them onto the hub.

REVISION
After trying this out I have come to the conclusion that smaller is better. I think the original 30mm hub was a little bit too small, and now I think that my 50mm hub was too big. It works, but it is rather sloppy. I made an adapter ring to step down the 50mm hub to a 32mm hub. It's a press fit, you don't need any glue, but you will need to force it in.
I enlarged the original 30mm hub to 32mm. hub-1. Hub-2 has the adapter built in.
I made 3 different length of arms, short, medium, and long. The shortest arms need to be glued in, the other 2 will screw in. I found that my little spools of filament were in about these 3 different sizes.
I also made a driver. It is tapered like a cone, so it fits into a 32mm hub. I put a 1/4" square socket on the back side so I can plug in a 1/4" socket to 1/4" hex adapter and spin it with a cordless screwdriver.
Here's a video:
https://youtu.be/rB5SNeqlLPc

This OpenSCAD library creates models of metric external retaining rings.

This is based on the standard: ANSI B27.7-1977,R1999

These rings are also Part# as follows 3AM1-[XX] ( where [XX] is shaft diameter in mm)

usage:
ANSI_3AM1(S);

After I started looking I wasn't happy with the accuracy of the Gorillapod base. The result is that I redesigned the Gorillapod base.

I also wanted the 5mm nut holder to fully capture the nut.

I printed this with support, due to the large overhang on the captured nut.
The slope on the Gorillapod base is 0.4mm over 31.5mm. If you don't print this at hi-res, it quite likely will not fit.

Sorry about the average photos.

description.text:
Newest Update: I had to man-mode those feet into place. Essentially, I had to place each foot on a flat surface, line up the hole in the base while holding it parallel to the flat surface, lay the flat of my scraper across the top of it, place the palm of my hand onto the top of the scraper, and start putting weight onto it until it popped into place. I went back and looked at my file, thinking I needed to increase the tolerance for the feet, but, as it turned out, I had put zero tolerance into the redesign. I have fixed the stl and uploaded it.

Update 2: I fixed the problems with the feet. I haven't printed them yet, but I'll post pictures once I have. Probably tomorrow.

Update 1: There's a slight problem with the feet for this design. Upon printing in a different material, the fit was so tight that one of the feet broke off. I am currently working on fixing this by creating wider legs that are less affected by the jerk of the extruder assembly.

Just a small straw holder with feet and holes in the bottom for air flow (in case you wash straws, like the Tervis reusable straws).

Fit: Had a failed cylinder, but I was able to use it to test the fit. Cylinder fits well, although, because of the failure, I had trim aberrations on the top of the cylinder to get the top rim to fit. Tolerances are .15 mm, so everything is snug.

Inner diameter is 41 inches.

Feet: I recommend printing the feet one at a time. It's only a few minutes, but it allows for a cleaner print on the small rod. I had to use a 2 mm allen wrench in the holes at the bottom of the base because of aberrations. Just stuck it in and rotated it. From there, I had to slowly twist the feet into the holes (also due to aberrations). It worked, but it was slow going.

STL Files: I oriented the objects into the best orientation for printing.

Print Size: 62 x 62 x 103 mm (based on largest sizes of any of the four parts)

Questions? Let me know if you think I should change anything. Specifically, I don't know if I like the airflow holes in the base. Not sure if I need a different design, maybe larger holes.

title: OpenSCAD HD Stepper Motors and Gearbox mockups

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD library for displaying high detail, visually accurate stepper motors, with or without gearbox, for use in mockups of larger assemblies (eg. a RepRap 3D printer, or other robots).

There are Nema11 and Nema17 versions currently, but the script could probably be adapted for other sizes of stepper motors as well..

This model is not intended to be 3D printed, but for visualizing in OpenSCAD, checking fit of assemblies, making pretty screenshots and animations, etc.

Motor and gearbox internals are not modeled accurately(or at all!), their beauty is only skin deep.

This script requires the Open Source BOLTS library by jreinhardt for the hex cap bolts.

description.text:
Printrbot camera holder

If you haven't tried Octopi you should... It's an amazing project - kudos to the authors - and it works really well with my Printrbot SImple Metal.

That said, as soon as I got things to work it became clear that positioning the Raspberry PI and the camera would be a pain. So I decide to print a holder to make sure the gizmo always stays in the right position, specially when printing. I ended up opting for a holder that attaches to the back of the printer, and extends to the left to connect to a Raspberry Pi case - for this project, I used a LEGO compatible SmartiPi case.

For extra support, you can fix the holder to the back of the printer using the existing metal screw.

title: Nissan and Infiniti Key fob fix

description.text: Both of the key fobs for my 2003 Infiniti G35 have broken and no longer stay on my key ring. The friction fits over the existing key fob, after removal of the broken attachment pieces, and retains use of the panic button. A small dab of glue could be used to more securely attach the repair, but the is about 0.030" interference/taper to the part that keeps it snug to the contour of the fob. Nissan and Infiniti used the same fob of many years, although I don't know the exact models it fits.

title: 120mm fan to 100mm flat profile duct system side mount

description.text:
This adapter enables to attach a 120mm fan to a 100mm flat profile duct system (used for kitchen or bathroom ventilation). In contrary to the available fan adapters, this adapter attaches the fan to the side of the duct system.
To attach the adapter, cut out the opening and drill the 4 holes. Use some silicone glue if you like.

title: BPS v4 Extruder BL Touch bracket
